content:
I'm stuck on the level of the Set Theory Game mentioned above: https://adam.math.hhu.de/#/g/djvelleman/stg4/world/FamCombo/level/6
I fail to see how to make the the hypothesis 'relevant' for the rest of the proof. I managed to prove some other set relations based on it, for example:
image.png
However, perhaps because I'm missing a sense of direction, I fail to make real inroads into proving the goal.
Does anyone have a hint on how I should try to use the (original) hypothesis?

There are some steps at the beginning of this one that you should do without thinking:

  1. Introduce an arbitrary x of type U.
  2. Assume x ∈ ⋃₀ F ∩ ⋃₀ G.
  3. Unpack the meaning of the assumption in step 2, and see what it tells you.
  4. Unpack the meaning of the goal at this point, which is x ∈ ⋃₀ (F ∩ G), to see what you have to do to complete the proof.

Have you done those steps?

If not: Don't worry about how to make the hypothesis 'relevant'. Do the steps above.

If so, then you know that to complete the proof you need to come up with some t ∈ F ∩ G such that x ∈ t. This is the tricky part. You almost have what you need in the assumptions, but not quite. Now is the time to think about how the hypothesis is relevant to completing the proof.

Thank you for the reply!
During my 'first go' at the problem the steps you describe are indeed what I did. Just in case I missed something I re-did that just now (see picture:
image.png
).
It seems indeed like the assumptions are very close to what I need, but I fail to see how to use the hypothesis to provide the 'missing piece of the puzzle'.
Perhaps my problem stems from the fact that I don't see how to 'connect' the hypothesis to these rewritten terms in the assumption/goal. It feels to me like either the hypothesis needs more unpacking or I would have to find matching terms in the unpacked version. Since I didn't manage to find a way to unpack the hypothesis I started to do all sorts of rewrites with the hypothesis & unpacked assumption/goal (as shown in my previous message) to try to find the connection that I am currently not recognizing.
Do you have a hint what I am missing?

On my phone, so have not verified formally. I think you have to use w as the witness. You know it's in F and contains x, so it suffices to show that it's also in G. Assume by contradiction that it's in G^c. Then x is in the LHS of h1 but not in the RHS. Qed

To prove the goal, you have to figure out what to plug in for t. You need something that is an element of both F and G, and that contains x as an element (what Ruben called a "witness" in his message). Looking at your assumptions, it seems like w and v are likely choices (or perhaps some combination of them). You know w is in F and x is in w, so if you could prove w ∈ G you could use w as the witness. You know v is in G and x is in v, so if you could prove v ∈ F then you could use v as the witness. So now is the time to look at h1 and see if it would help you prove either of those.

Notice that h1 involves F ∩ Gᶜ, so you might be able to use it to reason about something that is in F but not G. That suggests Ruben's strategy: try to use proof by contradiction to prove w ∈ G, so that you can use w as the witness.

Thank you both, I got it now!
I somehow didn't come up with attempting to prove w ∈ G, instead of trying to prove the whole thing 'directly'. Feels a bit silly now but I guess it's a good learning moment. (Special thanks to Dan Velleman for making the game, I'm having a lot of fun practicing mathematics/lean this summer vacation!)
Thijs Vromen has marked this topic as resolved.
